captions.text:
Talking about a little
miscommunication,

I want to go over some real
basic cat body language

that you probably
said, oh he means this.

And it is completely
in left field.

The first one,
Halloween cat, right?
You've seen it before.

Cat with arched back, tail up in
the air, and making themselves
totally puffed up.

And we interpret
that as aggression.

In reality what it is, is
pretty much the opposite.
It's fear.

The cat will blow
up, sort of tough,

in order to make themselves
appear bigger, because they're

afraid of something
that just happened.

The second one, the old, cat
laying on his or her back,
right?

Now, when you see your dog
lay on his or her back,
you go in for the tummy rub.

Those of you who have reached
in to rub your cat's belly,
you get bit or scratched.

I call this the cat hug,
because what they're doing

is exposing the most
vulnerable part of themselves,
their midline.

If you are facing a
potential predator,

this is that place that you
do not want exposed, right?

When a human hugs
another human, we

are exposing our midline
to that other person.

It is a mutual show of
risk-taking and emotional
trust.

Cats do the same thing
by showing you that.

That does not mean, come
on in for a belly rub.

Now let's talk about the
big one, the wagging tail.

Folks are looking at their cat
through dog-colored glasses

and are saying, this
means my cat is happy.

As a matter of fact, they are
usually saying the opposite.

Now, cats will start
to get worked up,

start to get a little agitated
to static in the environment
by absorbing that energy.

It's almost like it
comes in this way,

and then it gets
stuck in the tail.

And then, how am I suppose to
get this energy out of my body,
you know?

And then, it starts
getting worse, right?

And then by the time
they are ready to pounce

on you or anybody, or
explode with their staticky
frustration, it is like this.

We talked in the past
about the miscommunication

that is inherent with cat
overstimulation aggression.

So that is, you're sitting
there petting the cat-- pet,
pet, pet, pet, pet.
Suddenly, chomp.
You get bit.

The other one we talked about a
little bit was play aggression.

Your ankles get
attacked, but why?

Because your cat wants to
play and is not getting that
play attention.

We've even talked about how
your cat can pee on the couch,
for instance.
You're like, why do you hate me?

An insecure cat will
pee on something

to mingle their scent
with yours, as if to say,

you and me, buddy,
we're compadres, right?

So whether it is Halloween
cat, whether it is the cat hug

--the belly rub that
we go in for, which we

shouldn't-- whether it is
the play aggression attack,

the overstimulation
aggression attack,

whether it is the wagging tail,
these are all ways that we can

take off the
dog-colored glasses,

take off the
human-colored glasses.

Look at your cat through
cat-colored glasses,

their motivations, what
their reality is, and you'll

spend a lot less time
misconstruing, getting

angry, projecting, doing
all those dangerous things

that we tend to do more
with cats than dogs

for sure, but pretty
much anybody else.
So that's it for today, folks.

You can find me where you
find anybody these days,

whether it's on Twitter,
Facebook, YouTube.

The Animalist Network
has me in spades
these days, so watch Animalist.

And also, don't forget, make
some comments down below,
subscribe to my feed.

You'll find out what's going on,
like for instance, the Google

Hangout that is coming
up very soon now.

We're going to be talking,
more specifically than not,
about litter box issues.

But you know me, we're going
to go all over the map.

All right folks,
until the next time

we speak, all light, all
love, all mojo to you.
Love you.
THEME SONG: You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm not a bad cat.
You're a bad cat.
I'm just misunderstood.
Meow.

title: 6 Things Your Cat is Saying to You

comments.text:
Hello Jackson, I enjoy your videos quite a bit and have used your advice, 
it's been very helpful to me and my seven year old Maine Coon, Minnie so 
thank you so much.

That being said, I do have a question involving playtime. Like most Maine 
Coons, Minnie is very intelligent. She's probably the smartest cat I've 
ever had. So I'd take out her toys to play with and she'll play for about 
five minutes or so but then stop and look at me as if to say "Okay, I'm 
bored now." I've switched up toys as often as possible but it's the same 
reaction every time.

I understand you're busy so I'm not expecting a response. But if you (or 
anyone else on here) has any suggestions to keep Minnie interested during 
playtime, then I'll be grateful.﻿

comments.text: My cats both love to have their bellies rubbed ﻿

He's the sweetest guy! And cats are awesome! All we have to do is stop and 
really see what they need! In my case was a little more atention and love !﻿

comments.author: zcdarktide

comments.text:
I  PET MY CAT,  AND  IT ATTACKS! WHAT'S GOING ON?
Cats are fun, mischievous and they have cattitude. What do I mean by 
cattitude? It’s not just them acting like they are better than you, its 
about how they express themselves to let you know how they are feeling in 
the moment. 

Loving one second, and then biting or scratching the next can be really 
confusing for any cat owner. Their attitude  probably leaves you wondering 
what did I do to deserve the bite or scratch?

Our family cat Sawyer has always wanted her attention on her terms. I would 
lay down on the bed and she would come over and rub up against my hand and 
then curl up along the side of me. While I watched television, I would pet 
her and rub her head. Then out of nowhere she would bite my hand very hard. 
OUCH! I would yell and she would slowly saunter away looking back at me 
while swishing her tail back and forth. What did I do to deserve that I 
would say to her as she  would jump off the bed.

What I missed while I was watching television were her visual queues 
letting me know that she did not want me to pet her anymore. She gave me 
the signs through visual signals, but I was not paying attention to them 
and I paid the price with a hard bite on the hand.

What are some of the signs you should be looking for that will let you know 
that your cat has had enough?

• Fur on the back twitching
• Tail beginning to swish side to side. This may be a small movement side 
to side at the tip of the tail and then become a more aggressive movement 
as time goes on.
• Whiskers moving back along the face
• Ears moving to a back position

Watching for the visual queues your cat makes can prevent an unwanted bite 
or scratch and improve your overall relationship with your cat. Remember, 
If you are getting cattitude, maybe you didn't see the visual signs of what 
your cat was trying to tell you.

In the video below, Jackson Galaxy reviews cat body language and explains 
in more detail what they are saying to you.﻿
comments.author: Tick Tock Dog Walks™

comments.author: jones0898

comments.text:
QUESTIONS - i have 2, one is about 11/Dale (had a brother Chip), the other 
is right about a year old/ziggy.

dale loves being outside.
ziggy is begging to go outside. 
we live in a condo, we have common ground.  99% of our neighbors love dale 
(he's a great hunter and not afraid to keep foxes and skunks away.  the 1% 
have made our life almost miserable off and on for about 12 years.  

dale rings a bell to go outside for the bathroom (i think he's used the cat 
box 3 times in 10 years, because of a big snow fall once, this boy has 
litteraly waited almost 24 hours to use the box, he'd look outside for a 
few seconds and turn around into the house about 4 times, but after around 
24 hourse he hit the box).  if you don't get him out with the bell, he 
scratches, pulls, hangs from the door knob and tries to open it and he does 
the same to get in.  (he taught himself watching our dog).  so has wrecked 
our screens on the bottom and trim around the door.  he's always been very 
healthy. recently, i made him wait to go outside because he just came in 
(he has kept us up and down at times), so i told him to wait a while (i've 
been trying to keep him in during the day and out when most neighbors are 
sleeping).  this time, he ran to the litter box. i felt really bad and his 
schedule was moving fine for a few years and now i can't get him back on 
it.  i'm a little afraid to not run  to his beck and call now - am i over 
thinking this?

also, ignoring dale will get our walls sliced up bad...i really hate 
getting up at 3/4/5 am, any other suggestions?  i've tried putting him out 
30-60 min before wed, sometimes this works.

i have also been thinking about the electronic collar/invisible fence for 
both of them.  i would like to know your thoughts on those for cats.  we do 
not have a way, nor are we allowed to build any fencing of any kind on our 
patio, it's totally open and has to stay that way.  at this point the 
yearling has not been outside at all.  

i also want to know what you think about walking cats on a leash.

how do you keep a cat from climbing the face of curio cabinets?

how do you use the horn, sticky tape in places that are super hard or not 
able to set them up in - like the second he would jump on the shelf it 
would fall with everything else, so it doesn't seem that he would learn 
from those devices.﻿
comments.author: SOLUTIONZbY kAT

comments.author: thisherecat2

comments.text:
out of the 5 cats I've owned they all love their belly rubbed and will purr 
as soon as you touch them there. Is this unusual or something I should 
actually be concerned about seeing as so many cats hate it/are made 
uncomfortable by it? or does it just mean their cool with it because its 
never been used to harm them or constrict them? All of my cats have been 
really chill. They let us hold them on their back and they purr, they let 
us touch their paws, rub their bellies, play with their tails, and show no 
signs of aggression, fear, or tension a good 80% of the time. I always 
figured they simply enjoyed it. They come running when I call them by name 
and they even listen to verbal commands like Stop and Down and so on so I 
always thought they just trusted me.
I don't want to be harming my cat and not realizing it so I'd really 
appreciate feed back on this. Are belly rubs/touching of paws and 
tails/laying them on their back bad even if they seem to enjoy it?﻿

comments.author: Krassimir Cavalerra (CK)

comments.text:
Sir, my cat completely and fully hates me.. I adopted him, Apollo, about 2 
years ago. He hides from me. He does meow at me but he acts like he's 
afraid of me. How do I get him to like me?﻿
comments.author: Anthony Pearson

comments.text:
+Anthony Pearson Another thing you could try - when approaching him you 
could crouch down so you're not towering over him and therefore making 
yourself less of a threat, coupling that with slower movements, coaxing and 
patience you could earn some more trust with him by showing yourself to him 
in a non-threatening way.
Something else would be that you could also give him the slow blink, or 
otherwise an 'I love you'.
comments.author: Hero.

comments.text: Thanks boss
comments.author: Anthony Pearson

comments.text:
+Anthony Pearson I have a cat who acted like that. She used to be feral and 
it also turned out that she's partially deaf. It took years but eventually 
she came around. Now she's really loving and runs to me when she sees me 
and climbs up to sit on my shoulders. If your cat was feral or in an 
abusive home it'll take them a while. You just have to be patient and show 
them that you're not going to hurt them through your body language. One 
thing I did was, I would feed her then before she could scurry away I would 
pick her up and sit with her on my lap and talk to her. It took forever for 
her to even let me pet her and even longer for her to let me use both hands 
to pet her. She used to shrink away when I would raise my hands to pet her 
but now she's the most openly affectionate cat I've ever had.
comments.author: ThatShitCrayZ

comments.text:
+Anthony Pearson  well he eats from you (what you put down) so he must 
trust you...try tuna, human tuna, as a treat BUT only offer him little bits 
from your hand/fingers. You'll have to sit very still, not move but I just 
bet he'd lick tuna water/juice (not the oil stuff) with a little bite of 
tune right off your fingers....may be not right away, but try and see if 
you can build him up to it.For some play, try a very long shoe string (or 
any string really), again you sitting very still and slowly pull the string 
towards you, then kind of flicking it away again with out you moving (well 
your arm will need to move but you know what I'm getting at)  =)Good luck 
w/Apollo and keep trying - love always wins eventually.
comments.author: TemeryN

comments.text:
Thank u for responding. Apollo doesn't dig me at all. I can't play w him BC 
as soon as I move in any direction, he scurries. 
I live by myself so I am the only one putting food down. I tried treats but 
he doesn't eat them.
comments.author: Anthony Pearson

comments.text:
+Anthony Pearson  Hi, first good on you for adopting and sticking w/Apollo 
for 2 yrs. Some cats are just shy it's the way they are. We have 1 cat 
going on 16 yrs and if hubby raises his voice (even to cheer a football 
game) she goes running off like she did something wrong. Lots of patience 
and lots of treats and lots of playtime are your best bets for "getting him 
to like you". He probably loves you but just shows it in his own way. Also 
make sure you're the one who puts his food down for him, most cats "love" 
whomever it is that feeds them in my experience.  =)
comments.author: TemeryN

wounds? what is it saying when it urinates in other peoples car air vents. 
on porches etc? Seriously cats enjoy cuasing damage to stuff and harm to 
people simply becuase their owners refuse to keep them inside at night and 
force them out with no tags,collar, i.d. chip or leash all alone to get hit 
by cars, attcked by other animals or finally taken out by home owners tied 
of the cats predations. The cat owner should not have the cat unless they 
know how to care properly for it.﻿

comments.author: Janet Morrissette

comments.text:
To all the people saying "oh mah kitteh love belly rubz, you so wrong".... 
no he's still right, and you need to think critically.

It's still all a matter of trust. Your cat probably adores belly rubs from 
you, but have you ever noticed how other peoples cats usually aren't so 
receptive? That's because they don't trust you like they trust their 
owners. You've probably seen the same thing when your friends come over and 
try to pet your cat.

Lesson: Showing the belly is NOT an invitation for a belly rub, unless your 
cat trust you 110%. And don't go trying to pet the belly of a cat that 
isn't yours.﻿
